questions.question_text: Which of the following shows projected project expenditures?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I selected Answer C
I think WBS is correct. This website explicitly states that https://www.workbreakdownstructure.com/

Answer A is the correct answer, taken from Sybex Project+ Study Guide, 2nd Edition, page 80. 

"A WBS is one of the fundamental building blocks of project planning. It will be used as an input to numerous other planning processes. It's also the basis for estimating activity duration, assigning resources to activities, estimating work effort, and creating a budget."

Cash burn rate would be a good answer but burn rate is measuring the project expenditures to-date rather than projected project expenditures. As for Cash Flow, I couldn't find much information on Google regarding that as it relates to Project Management and the only related definitions, at least in title, are cash flow techniques and not cash flow schedules, which includes Discounted Cash Flow, Net Present Value, and Internal Rate of Return which are more economic models predicting revenue.

I feel the answer should be a cash flow schedule because it shows the estimated and schedules cash disbursement of the project by time period. 

WBS doesn't show the projected project expenditures but rather the work that has to be done to successfully produce a deliverable. I think it is confusing it with the Cost Breakdown Structure.

choices.D: TheWBS will aid in determining which resources are required for the project.
choices.C: TheWBS will be required if the project manager has the time available to complete it.

discussion.content:
A. Using the WBS will help prevent work from slipping or being forgotten.
D. The WBS will aid in determining which resources are required for the project.

Explanation: The WBS is an essential tool for breaking down a project into manageable work packages, which aids in preventing work from being overlooked or delayed. Additionally, by breaking down the project, the project manager can determine which resources are required for each package of work. These points are likely to resonate with the other managers, making the benefits of the WBS more apparent.

questions.question_text: A team member was assigned a new task during a meeting. The team member did not complete the task by the end of the phase, and the PM is looking for evidence to escalate the issue. Which of the following documents could help in this situation?

discussion.content:
A responsibility assignment matrix (RAM) should include the following elements:

A. Responsible: the person or team responsible for completing the task or activity.
B. Accountable: the person who has ultimate responsibility for the completion of the task or activity.
C. Consulted: the person or team who is consulted for input or advice on the task or activity.
D. Informed: the person or team who is kept informed of the progress or status of the task or activity.

Therefore, the correct answer is A. Responsible, accountable, consulted, informed.

If the question is ever about focus during the meeting, most likely it has to do with agenda and keeping the meeting on track for which it was being held. The other options will be discussed during the meeting, having an agenda will set the track for this to happen in an organized way.

Selected Answer: C
"When a meeting is scheduled, an*** agenda*** should be written and distributed beforehand so the attendees know what to expect during the meeting."

Project kickoff meetings are particularly important, because they set the tone for communications throughout the duration of the project. ***The agenda*** for a project team that is meeting for the first time will include:
• Reinforcing project assignment documents. <------ Charter
• Introducing the team members.
• Stating the project goals and expectations.
• Sharing contact information of the team members.
• Establishing timelines and assigning project tasks.<----- there is schedule 
• Discussing potential project issues if any.<----- Risk 
• Setting the ground rules.

CompTIA official guide page 319
